The mandatory energy efficiency standards for clothes washers, established by DOE rulemaking activities and federal laws.

This is the estimated annual energy use of the clothes washer under typical conditions, including the energy used by the washer and the energy needed to heat the water used by the clothes washer with an electric water heater. Unlike MEF, the estimated annual energy use does not address how effective the washer is at removing moisture from the wash load and thus reducing the energy needed to fully dry a load in the clothes dryer. It is based on an annual usage of 1,074 loads per year for multi-family and 1,483 loads per year for laundromat applications, or around 21 and 29 loads per week respectively, as referenced by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix J2. Actual energy consumption will vary depending on various factors such as the amount of laundry done, the size of the loads, and the settings chosen.

WF is the water performance metric for ENERGY STAR qualified clothes washers. The lower the WF, the more efficient the clothes washer. The metric has units: gallons/cycle/ft3, and is calculated as the quotient of total weighted per-cycle water consumption divided by the capacity of the clothes washer. A geothermal heat pump uses the thermal energy of the ground or groundwater to provide residential space conditioning and/or domestic water heating. A geothermal heat pump model normally consists of one or more factory-made assemblies that include indoor conditioning and/or domestic water heat exchanger(s), compressors, and a ground-side heat exchanger. A geothermal heat pump model may provide space heating, space cooling, domestic water heating, or a combination of these functions and may also include the functions of liquid circulation, thermal storage, air circulation, air cleaning, dehumidifying or humidifying. A geothermal heat pump system generally consists of one or more geothermal heat pump models, the ground heat exchanger(s), the air and/or hydronic space conditioning distribution system(s), temperature controls, and thermal storage tanks.

Clothes washers with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering your electric bill. For combination all-in-one washer-dryer products the washer and dryer must meet connected criteria.

CEF is the energy performance metric for ENERGY STAR clothes dryers; the higher the CEF the more efficient the clothes dryer. The metric has units lbs/kWh and is calculated by dividing the weight of the test load by the sum of the per cycle standby and off mode energy consumption and either the total per-cycle electricity dryer energy consumption or the total per-cycle gas dryer energy consumption expressed in kilowatt hours (kWh).

The depth of the product.
Integrated Water Factor (IWF) is a measure of water efficiency that considers gallons of water consumed per cubic foot of capacity. The lower the IWF, the more water efficient the clothes washer.

For combination all-in-one washer-dryers, the Calculated CEF – Max Dry is a measure of the dryer’s energy performance in a more energy consumptive setting, namely the normal cycle with the highest dryness setting as defined in the ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2017 criteria. The Calculated CEF – Max Dry should not be directly compared to the CEF field, which is tested using the medium dryness setting, and represents a rated rather than measured value. The CEF metric has units lbs/kWh and is calculated by dividing the weight of the test load by the sum of the per cycle standby and off mode energy consumption and either the total per-cycle electricity dryer energy consumption or the total per-cycle gas dryer energy consumption expressed in kilowatt hours (kWh).

For combination all-in-one washer-dryers, features applicable to the clothes dryer may include drum light, wrinkle prevention option, steam cycle, sanitization cycle, filter cleaning indicator, energy monitor/indicator, time remaining display, and supplementary drying system.

A unique string of characters used to identify models with the same performance characteristics. This sequence is generated by certification bodies and is reported as a single row of data on the lists of certified products.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

IMEF is the energy performance metric for ENERGY STAR certified clothes washers. The higher the IMEF, the more energy efficient the clothes washer. The metric has units: ft3/kWh/cycle, and is calculated as the quotient of the capacity of the clothes container divided by the total clothes washer energy consumption per cycle, with such energy consumption expressed as the sum of the machine electrical energy consumption, the hot water energy consumption, the energy required for removal of the remaining moisture in the wash load, and the combined low-power mode energy consumption. For example, if a clothes washer has a tub volume of 4.0 cubic feet and a total clothes washer energy consumption per cycle of 10 kWh/cycle, then the IMEF is 2.5.

Highly energy efficient heat pump technology typically heats, dehumidifies and circulates air in the dryer drum, so no vent is required. A Heat Pump model solely uses heat pump technology to dry clothes, while a Hybrid Heat Pump model uses a combination of heat pump technology and traditional electric resistance heating technology.

For combination all-in-one washer-dryers, the estimated energy test cycle time is the time taken to complete the test cycle necessary for ENERGY STAR certification. Products must complete the energy test cycle in less than 80 minutes in order to be certified as ENERGY STAR. The estimated test cycle time does not reflect actual consumer cycle times which vary as a result of load size, dampness, and composition.

Actual energy consumption will vary on your usage patterns, including how often your run the dryer, what cycle you select, and load size. NOTE: For gas dryers the estimated annual energy use is expressed in kilowatt hours to allow for comparison, and represents the equivalent multi-source energy use of the product (e.g., natural gas or propane typically expressed in British thermal units (Btu)).

For combination all-in-one washer-dryers, the cycle selection and settings (temperature and dryness where separately selectable) as defined in the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix D2, Section 3.3, used for certification to ENERGY STAR.

Unlike IMEF, the estimated annual energy use does not address how effective the washer is at removing moisture from the wash load and thus reducing the energy needed to fully dry a load in the clothes dryer. It is based on an annual usage of 295 loads per year, or around 6 loads per week, as referenced by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix J2. columns_description: The cooking-energy efficiency percentage for a combination oven operating in steam mode is the quantity of energy input to the food product (i.e., potatoes) during the cooking process; expressed as a percentage of the quantity of energy input to the oven during the cooking-energy efficiency tests.

The cooking-energy efficiency percentage for an oven operating in convection mode is the quantity of energy input to the food product (i.e., potatoes) during the cooking process; expressed as a percentage of the quantity of energy input to the oven during the cooking-energy efficiency tests.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
The average rate of energy consumed in kW by the electric combination oven operating in steam mode while idling at a ready-to-cook temperature set point.
The average water consumption rate of a convection or rack oven operating in steam injection mode during steam injection periods expressed in gallons per minute.

An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. The measured amount of energy an electric oven in convection mode consumes during the pre-heat test.

The approach used for all ovens to generate steam while operating in steam mode (e.g. boiler/steam generator, boilerless, or spritzer/injector).
Designates the type of commercial oven model per ASTM F1495-20 specification, as either Type I (table, countertop, and stand mounted units) or Type II (floor and roll-in units).
The number of half-size sheet pans a half-size convection oven can accommodate.

bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance

by EPA.
The average water consumption rate of a combination oven operating in steam mode during cooking periods expressed in gallons per pan.
For gas ovens with variable Btu/h input, each available input shall be tested individually and meet the cooking energy efficiency and idle energy rate requirements of the specification.

For ovens with variable Btu/h input, each available input shall be tested individually and meet the cooking energy efficiency and idle energy rate requirements of the specification. The calculated gas or electric oven convection mode idle energy rate value.

The baking-energy efficiency percentage for a rack oven operating in baking mode is the quantity of energy input to the food product (i.e., frozen pies) during the baking process; expressed as a percentage of the quantity of energy input to the oven during the cooking-energy efficiency tests.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
The number of  full-size sheet pans a full-size convection oven can accommodate.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification

The cooking-energy efficiency production capacity of a combination oven operating in steam mode is expressed in pounds per hour. The production rate is the average rate at which the oven brings a specified food product to a specified final temperature.
The number of full-size (GN 1/1) steam pans that a half- or full-size combination oven can accommodate.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

The average rate of auxillary electric energy consumed (i.e., fan motor, lighting, controls, etc.) in Watts by the gas convection oven or combination oven operating in convection mode while idling at a ready-to-cook temperature set point.
The average rate of primary energy consumed by gas ovens (i.e., gas is primary heat source for gas ovens).

For ovens with variable kW input, each available input shall be tested individually and meet the cooking energy efficiency and idle energy rate requirements of the specification. The calculated gas or electric oven convection mode idle energy rate value.

Designates type of commercial oven model in simple terms as one of the following: electric convection oven, gas convection oven, electric combination oven, gas combination oven, gas single rack oven, or gas double rack oven.
Gas or electric fuel type.
The average water consumption rate of a combination oven operating in convection mode during cooking periods expressed in gallons per pan.
The rack oven has a default setback mode during extended periods of non-use where the oven is idling at a reduced temperature set point.
The measured amount of time an oven requires to pre-heat in convection mode.
The measured amount of energy an electric oven in steam mode consumes during the pre-heat test.
The measured amount of energy a gas oven in convection mode consumes during the pre-heat test.
The average water consumption rate of a combination oven operating in convection mode during idle periods expressed in gallons per hour per pan.

The cooking-energy efficiency production capacity of a convection oven or a combination oven operating in convection mode is expressed in pounds per hour. The production rate is the average rate at which the oven brings a specified food product to a specified final temperature.

The average rate of auxillary electric energy consumed (i.e., fan motor, lighting, controls, etc.) in Watts by the gas combination oven operating in steam mode while idling at a ready-to-cook temperature set point.
The average water consumption rate of a combination oven operating in steam mode during idle periods expressed in gallons per hour per pan.
The average rate of energy consumed in Btu/h by the gas  combination oven operating in steam mode while idling at a ready-to-cook temperature set point.
The measured amount of time an oven requires to pre-heat in steam mode.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

Designates the size of the commercial convection and combination oven model (but not gas rack ovens), according to the following options for Version 3.0: 1) Full-size convection oven (a convection oven that is able to accomodate standard full-size sheet pans measuring 18 x 26 x 1-inch); 2) Half-size convection oven (a convection oven that is able to accomodate half-sheet pans measuring 18 x 13 x 1-inch); 3) Full-size combination ovens (a combination oven that is able to accomodate two GN 1/1 steam pans measuring 20 3/4 x 12 3/4-inch, per rack or tray position); 4) Half-size combination ovens (a combination oven that is able to accomodate a one GN 1/1 steam pan measuring 20 3/4 x 12 3/4-inch, per rack or tray position); and two-third-size combination ovens (a combination oven that is able to accomodate one GN 2/3 steam pan measuring 13 3/4 x 12 3/4-inch, per rack or tray position). The Version 3.0 specification covers full-size and half-size electric convection ovens; full-size gas convection ovens; full- and half-size electric and gas combination ovens; two-third-size combination ovens.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

The baking-energy efficiency production capacity of a rack oven operating in baking mode is expressed in pounds per hour. The production rate is the average rate at which the oven brings a specified food product to a specified final temperature.
For electric ovens with variable kW input, each available input shall be tested individually and meet the cooking energy efficiency and idle energy rate requirements of the specification.
The measured amount of energy a gas oven in steam mode consumes during the pre-heat test.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Light Commercial HVAC
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 4.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Light Commercial HVAC that are effective as of January 1, 2023. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/heating_cooling/light_commercial_heating_cooling/key_product_criteria.
columns_description: UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The ability of the system to deliver sensible and latent heating when the outside air temperature is 47 F.

Indicates heat pumps that meet the ENERGY STAR cold climate criteria; cold climate heat pumps will provide better heating performance in low ambient temperatures, making these products an excellent choice for cold climate installations where the heat pump will be the sole heating source.
A measure of efficiency in the heating mode that represents the ratio of total heating capacity to electrical energy input, measured at 17 degrees F.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.
Meets EER2 requirements for efficient cooling at 95F.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
The ratio of the produced cooling effect of an air conditioner or heat pump to its net work input, expressed in Btu/watt-hour using 10 CFR part 431, Subpart F, §431.96, Table 1.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit. For light commercial HVAC models, model number indicates the outdoor model number.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

This column identifies whether the system uses a split system arrangement (remote condensing unit) or a single package system (all components are stored in a single cabinet). All VRF models are required to be listed as "Split System".

The capacity associated with the change in air enthalpy between the air entering the unit and the air leaving the unit, which includes both the latent (change in humidity ratio) and sensible (change in dry-bulb temperature) capacities expressed in Btu/h and include the heat of circulation fan(s) and motor(s).

IEER is a measure that expresses cooling part-load EER efficiency for commercial air-conditioners, heat pumps, and VRF Multi-Splits on the basis of weighted operation at various load capacities using 10 CFR part 431, Subpart F, §431.96, Table 1.

The total heating output of a central air-conditioning heat pump during its normal annual usage period for heating, expressed in Btu's and divided by the total electric power input, expressed in Btu/Wh using 10 CFR part 431, Subpart F, §431.96, Table 1.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

The ratio of the total heat removed from the conditioned space during the annual cooling season to the total electrical energy consumed by the air conditioner or heat pump during the same season, expressed in Btu/Wh using 10 CFR part 431, Subpart F, §431.96, Table 1.
Indicates the type of refrigerant used in the model.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

Equipment Capacity Designations (based on Cooling Capacity): Very Small: <65,000 BTU/h Small: ≥65,000 BTU/h and <135,000 BTU/h Large: ≥135,000 BTU/h and <240,000 BTU/h  Commercial Unitary Air Conditioner (CUAC): An air conditioner model consists of one or more factory-made assemblies that normally include an evaporator or cooling coil(s), compressor(s), and condenser(s). Air conditioners provide the function of air cooling, and may include the functions of air circulation, air cleaning, dehumidifying, or humidifying.   Commercial Unitary Heat Pump (CUHP): A heat pump model consists of one or more factorymade assemblies that normally include an indoor conditioning coil(s), compressor(s), and outdoor coil(s), including means to provide a heating function. Heat pumps shall provide the function of air heating with controlled temperature, and may include the functions of air cooling, air circulation, air cleaning, dehumidifying, or humidifying.  Gas/Electric Package Unit: Single package commercial package air-conditioning and heating equipment with gas heating and electric air-conditioning that is often installed on a slab or a roof.   Variable Refrigerant Flow Multi-Split (VRF) Air Conditioner: A unit of commercial package airconditioning and heating equipment that is configured as a split system air conditioner incorporating a single refrigerant circuit, with one or more outdoor units, at least one variablespeed compressor or an alternate compressor combination for varying the capacity of the system by three or more steps, and multiple indoor fan coil units, each of which is individually metered and individually controlled by an integral control device and common communications network and which can operate independently in response to multiple indoor thermostats. Variable refrigerant flow implies three or more steps of capacity control on common, inter-connecting piping.  Variable Refrigerant Flow Multi-Split (VRF) Heat Pump: A unit of commercial package airconditioning and heating equipment that is configured as a split system heat pump that uses reverse cycle refrigeration as its primary heating source and which may include secondary supplemental heating by means of electrical resistance, steam, hot water, or gas. The equipment incorporates a single refrigerant circuit, with one or more outdoor units, at least one variable-speed compressor or  an alternate compressor combination for varying the capacity of the system by three or more steps, and multiple indoor fan coil units, each of which is individually metered and individually controlled by a control device and common communications network, and which can operate independently in response to multiple indoor thermostats. Variable refrigerant flow implies three or more steps of capacity control on common, inter-connecting piping.on, inter-connecting piping.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower-GWP alternative refrigerant options for light commercial HVAC include R-32 and R-454B.
A measure of efficiency in the heating mode that represents the ratio of total heating capacity to electrical energy input, measured at 5 degrees F.

The ratio of the total heat removed from the conditioned space during the annual cooling season to the total electrical energy consumed by the air conditioner or heat pump during the same season, expressed in Btu/Wh using Proposed Appendix B1 at 86 FR 70316, 70346-70347 (Dec. 9, 2021).
The ability of the system to deliver sensible and latent heating when the outside air temperature is 5 F.
The ability of the system to deliver sensible and latent heating when the outside air temperature is 17 F.
The ratio of the produced cooling effect of an air conditioner or heat pump to its net work input, expressed in Btu/watt-hour using Proposed Appendix B1 at 86 FR 70316, 70346-70347 (Dec. 9, 2021).
A measure of efficiency in the heating mode that represents the ratio of total heating capacity to electrical energy input, measured at 47 degrees F.

The type of heating section the LCHVAC systems uses. Central air conditioners and heat pumps systems can use either all other heating section types (propane, gas, oil), electric resistance, or none. VRF Multi-Split systems either come with heat recovery or without heat recovery.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

The total heating output of a central air-conditioning heat pump during its normal annual usage period for heating, expressed in Btu's and divided by the total electric power input, expressed in Btu/Wh using Proposed Appendix B1 at 86 FR 70316, 70346-70347 (Dec. 9, 2021).

columns_description: Indicates whether STB can deliver ("server") or receive ("client") content through a Digital Living Network Alliance (DLNA) protocol such as RVU or VidiPath. DLNA-protocol servers can deliver content to a supported television without a Set-top Box at that endpoint.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
Total kWh allowance from Base and Adders as provided in the specification
Measured power according to the ENERGY STAR Set-top Box Test Method with the product in Deep Sleep State.
Indicates STB power type, AC or DC.

Measured power according to the ENERGY STAR Set-top Box Test Method where the product is connected to the mains power source, is not providing a primary function, and offers one or more user oriented or protective functions, such as internal sensors, clocks, and facilitation of remote control activation/deactivation.

Indicates that the product has one or more of the following functionalities in addition to the base functionality. Additional functionalities such as multi-room may be present but not tested by ENERGY STAR. 
a. Adv. Video Processing - capability to encode, decode, and/or transcode audio/video signals
b. CableCARD - capability to decrypt premium audio/video content and services and provide other network control functions via a plug-in conditional access module.
c. Digital Video Recorder (DVR) - capability to store video in a digital format to a rewritable disk drive or other non-volatile storage device integrated into the set-top box
d. DOCSIS® - The capability to distribute data and audio/video content over cable television infrastructure.
e. High Definition (HD) Resolution - capability to transmit or display video signals with resolution greater than or equal to 720p
f. Home Network Interface - capability to interface with external devices over a high bandwidth network (e.g., WiFi, MoCA, HPNA)
g. Multi-room - capability to provide independent audio/video content to multiple devices within a single family dwelling
h. Multi-stream - capability to deliver two or more simultaneous audio/video streams to a consumer display, thin-client/remote set-top box, or recording device
i. Removable Media Player - capability to decode digitalized audio/video signals on DVD or Blu-ray Disc optical media
j. Removable Media Player/Recorder - capability to decode and record digitalized audio/video signals on DVD or Blu-ray Disc optical media
When applicable, indicates the number and type of MIMO WiFi streams supported by STB.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
Measured power according to the ENERGY STAR Set-top Box Test Method with the product in Deep Sleep State.
This column indicates whether or not the product incorporates a state within Sleep mode characterized by reduced power consumption.
The column indicates whether or not the product has the capability to switch itself from On mode to Sleep mode after a predetermined period of time.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
Measured power according to the ENERGY STAR Set-top Box Test Method with the product activated and providing one or more primary functions, such as delivery of live or recorded audio/video content.
Calculation of expected energy consumption for a typical user over a one year period, expressed in units of kWh/year.  Actual annual energy consumption will vary depending on usage patterns.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Calculation of expected energy consumption for a typical user over a one year period, expressed in units of kWh/year.  Actual annual energy consumption will vary depending on usage patterns.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information

An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. This column includes alternative means to identify the model/model family (e.g., additional model names, additional model numbers, retailer SKUs, product descriptions).

The primary means of access to video content for a set-top box. All of the following base types may be configured as a simple set-top box that provides a single primary function, or as part of a complex set-top box that provides a primary function and one or more additional functionalities. a.Cable - receives television signals from a broadband, hybrid fiber/coaxial, or community cable distribution system with conditional access
b.Satellite - receives television signals from satellites
c.Internet Protocol (IP) - receives television/video signals encapsulated in Internet Protocol (IP) packets
d.Cable Digital Transport Adapter (DTA) - a minimally-configured set-top box with a primary function to receive television signals from a broadband, hybrid fiber/coaxial, or community cable distribution system
e.Terrestrial - receives television signals over the air or via community cable distribution system without conditional access
f.Thin-client/Remote - A set-top box that (1) is designed to interface between a multi-room set-top box and a TV (or other output device), (2) has no ability to directly interface with a Service Provider, and (3) relies solely on a multi-room set-top box for content
Indicates which adders were claimed by STB for certification. See enhanced functionality note for description of individual adders.

Measured power according to the ENERGY STAR Set-top Box Test Method where the product is connected to the mains power source, is not providing a primary function, and offers one or more user oriented or protective functions, such as internal sensors, clocks, and facilitation of remote control activation/deactivation.

bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
Measured power according to the ENERGY STAR Set-top Box Test Method with the product activated and providing one or more primary functions, such as delivery of live or recorded audio/video content.

Single-room indicates the product qualifies for ENERGY STAR when providing content to only one TV. Multi-room capability indicates models may be installed to provide independent audio/video content to multiple devices within a single family home.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Light Bulbs
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 2.0 and V2.1 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Lamps (Light Bulbs) that are effective as of January 2, 2017. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/lighting_fans/light_bulbs/key_product_criteria
columns_description: A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
The number of years the light bulb is covered under the manufacturer’s warranty.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

The appearance of the light is indicated by the Correlated Color Temperature (CCT) on the Kelvin scale. Lower Kelvin numbers like 2700-3000K mean the light appears more “warm” like incandescent; a CCT of 3500-4100K mean the light is whiter and higher temperatures like 5000-6500K would appear slightly bluer. Light appearance is indicated on bulb packaging.
Indicates whether the lamp meets the criteria to be recognized as connected.
The method of communications or connected protocol that a connected lamp uses.
The technology of the light bulb e.g. compact fluorescent light bulbs (CFL) or light emitting diode (LED).

The ratio of real power that flows to the light bulb versus the amount of power actually consumed. A light bulb with a lower power factor will draw more current than a light bulb with a higher power factor for the same amount of useful power transferred.
Center beam candle power (CBCP) the luminous intensity at the center of the beam, measured in candela (cd).
Whether the lamp is rated for use in enclosed fixtures.
Indicates the nominal purpose of the lamp, omnidirectional or general purpose, directional, or decorative.
The amount of power that a connected lamp draws when it is not producing light but in standby mode.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.
The maximum diameter of the light bulb in millimeters.
The maximum length of the light bulb in millimeters.
The connector at the bottom of the light bulb: Common base types include the “Edison” or “medium” screw base (E26), candelabra screw base (E12), and multiple pin bases (GU24, GU10) etc.

The shape of the light bulb. General purpose incandescent (i.e. 40W, 60W etc.) replacements include bare-spiral CFLs, and A-shape CFLs and LED bulbs. Globe or "G" type shapes are common for bathroom vanity lights, Reflector bulbs are commonly referred to as flood or spot lights and include R (reflector), bulged reflector (BR), parabolic aluminum reflector (PAR), multifaceted reflector (MR), etc. Decorative types include candle (C) shapes, and Other includes non-standard and less common CFL and LED shapes, etc.

The shape of the light bulb. General purpose incandescent (i.e. 40W, 60W etc.) replacements include bare-spiral CFLs, and A-shape CFLs and LED bulbs. Globe or "G" type shapes are common for bathroom vanity lights, Reflector bulbs are commonly referred to as flood or spot lights and include R (reflector), bulged reflector (BR), parabolic aluminum reflector (PAR), multifaceted reflector (MR), etc. Decorative types include candle (C) shapes, and Other includes non-standard and less common CFL and LED shapes, etc.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

A light bulb’s estimated lifetime in hours determined by operating a sample of bulbs according to industry test standards. For traditional bulbs like incandescent and CFLs the time that half of the test sample fails is considered rated life. For LED lighting the life is based on the estimated time for the product’s light output to decrease light 30%. By definition, some lamps will fail before their rated life and some will operate beyond their rated life. The ENERGY STAR specifications set minimum rated lifetimes and require extensive switching and long term testing to stress the products. Actual lifetime of products will vary depending on use.
A description of the reported light output, measured in lumens (not watts). To save energy, find the ENERGY STAR bulbs with the lumens you need, then choose the one with the lowest watts.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

Most bulbs are designed to operate on an on/off switch. However, some bulbs have been designed with features to perform in specialized applications, such as with dimmers or three-way control. Special features and compatibility with controls should be clearly marked on the product packaging, cut sheet or web site for the product.
Indicates if the lamp is capable of three way operation.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Indicates if the lamp manufacturer claims that the lamp is dimmable and meets the requirements in the specification.
The familiar wattage of the traditional bulb that this efficient bulb can replace using fewer watts.

The Color Rendering Index (CRI) of a light source is a measure of color quality and represents the degree of color shift objects undergo when illuminated by the light source as compared with the color of those same objects when illuminated by a reference source of comparable color temperature. The ENERGY STAR specifications require a CRI of at least 80. Incandescent lighting has a CRI of 100. Early fluorescent lighting had CRIs in the 60s, resulting in unpleasant appearance of skin tones.

The R9 value is not included in the Color Rendering Index (CRI) score but important for a light source to show red in objects with red in them, such as skin tones, natural wood tones, produce, meats, and artwork. Higher numbers represent more accurate rendering of red.
The minimum light output level of a lamp when operated on a dimmer. Typically expressed as a percentage.
The reported angle of the light distribution at which the luminous intensity is 1/2 of the center beam (in degrees).

The model number of the specific tested single configuration model of a non-Modular UPS or the minimum configuration model of a Modular UPS.  A Modular UPS is comprised of two or more single UPS modules, sharing one or more common frames and a common energy storage system, whose outputs, in normal mode of operation, are connected to a common output bus contained entirely within the frame(s). Modular UPSs may be used to provide redundancy, to scale capacity or both. For qualification of a Modular UPS Product Family, both the minimum and maximum configuration models are tested.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Vending Machines
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 4.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Refrigerated Beverage Vending Machines that are effective as of April 29, 2020.  A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/other/vending_machines/key_product_criteria.

bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower-GWP alternative refrigerant options for vending machines include R-290, R-600a, and R-744 (CO₂).
For rebuilt machines, a distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the OEM.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
Indoor/outdoor machines may be suitable for outdoor use or suitable for protected locations. Indoor machines are suitable for indoor use only (per UL Standard 541).
For models with an Accessory Low Power Mode, the accessories which are equipped with a low power mode.
The type of refrigerant used by the product.
For rebuilt machines, the model number of the energy efficiency component(s)/kit installed to meet ENERGY STAR requirements.

An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
The daily energy consumption value in kWh per day.
Vending machines eligible for ENERGY STAR may have a closed front door, glass front door, or live display front door.

Refrigerated beverage vending machines are either Class A or Class B. Combination vending machines are either Combination A or Combination B. 'A' types have mostly transparent fronts; 'B' types have mostly opaque fronts. Combination machines may contain two or more compartments separated by a solid partition. For detailed definitions see the RBVM product specification.
Refrigerated volume represents the volume of the interior cabinet where cold beverages are stored as measured by 10 CFR Part 431 Subpart Q, Appendix B.

The maximum quantity of standard product that can be dispensed from one full loading of the vending machine without further reload operations when used as recommended by the manufacturer (per ANSI/ASHRAE 32.1).

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

columns_description: A low power mode that the computer enters automatically after a period of inactivity or by manual selection. The power state in which the operating system and other software have completed loading, a user profile has been created, activity is limited to those basic applications that the system starts by default, and the computer is not in Sleep Mode. Desktop: A computer whose main unit is designed to be located in a permanent location, often on a desk or on the floor. Desktop computers are not designed for portability and are designed for use with an external display, keyboard, and mouse.

Integrated Computer: A desktop computer in which the computing hardware and display are integrated into a single housing, and which is connected to ac mains power through a single cable. Integrated desktop computers come in one of two possible forms: (1) a system where the display and computer are physically combined into a single unit; or (2) a system packaged as a single system where the display is separate but is connected to the main chassis by a dc power cord and both the computer and display are powered from a single power supply.

Notebook: A computer designed specifically for portability and to be operated for extended periods of time both with and without a direct connection to an ac mains power source.

Slate/tablet: A computing device designed for portability.

Portable All-in-one Computer: A computing device designed for limited portability.

Small-scale Server: A computer that typically uses desktop components in a desktop form factor, but is designed primarily to be a storage host for other computers. Small-scale Servers are designed to perform functions such as providing network infrastructure services (e.g., archiving) and hosting data/media.

Thin Client: An independently-powered computer that relies on a connection to remote computing resources to obtain primary functionality. Main computing functions (e.g., program execution, data storage, interaction with other Internet resources) are provided by the remote computing resources.

Workstation: A high-performance, single-user computer typically used for graphics, CAD, software development, financial and scientific applications among other compute intensive tasks.

Furthermore, the Computer has reached an Idle condition, but the Display is on, and Long Idle power management features have not engaged.
The default power-saving mode used by the computer.
The amount of memory installed in the model configuration tested as meeting Category D1 requirements.
The processing capability of the discrete graphics card installed in the model configuration tested as meeting Category 0 requirements, with a higher 'G number' indicating higher performance.
The number of Thunderbolt ports in the product.
Does the product support multi-channel memory functionality?
Does the product have integrated wireless 802.11 support?
The energy allowance provided by the ENERGY STAR specification.
The number of PCI Express x 8 interface slots in the product.
The brand of the central processing unit (CPU) installed in the model configuration tested as meeting Category I1 requirements
The brand of the central processing unit (CPU).
The number of USB 2.0 ports in the product.
The number of Thunderbolt 3 ports in the product.
Typical energy consumption of the model configuration tested as meeting Category 0 requirements.
The number of M.2 ports in the product, excluding Key M type M.2 ports.
The brand of the central processing unit (CPU) installed in the model configuration tested as meeting Category I2 requirements.
If "Yes", the model includes a touch screen.
Does the product have an ethernet port?

A low power mode that the computer enters automatically after a period of inactivity or by manual selection. A computer with Sleep capability can quickly “wake” in response to network connections or user interface devices with a latency of less than or equal to 5 seconds from initiation of wake event to system becoming fully usable including rendering of display.
The name of the operating system.

The power state in which the operating system and other software have completed loading, a user profile has been created, activity is limited to those basic applications that the system starts by default, and the computer is not in Sleep Mode. Furthermore, the Computer has reached an Idle condition, but the Display is on, and Long Idle power management features have not engaged.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Room Air Cleaners
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 2.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Room Air Cleaners that are effective as of October 17, 2020. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/appliances/air_purifiers_cleaners/key_product_criteria
columns_name: Pollen-Free Clean Air Delivery Rate per Watt
Dust-Free Clean Air Delivery Rate per Watt
Smoke-Free Clean Air Delivery Rate per Watt
Meets ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2023 Criteria
columns_description: A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a replacement filter by the manufacturer.

Indicates the primary type of filter, if the air cleaner has a filter. High-Efficiency Particulate Air filters or HEPA filters sometimes, also called True HEPA filters, have a minimum fractional particle removal efficiency of 99.97% for all particles of 0.3 μm diameter. Filters described as HEPA-Type or something other than “HEPA” or “True HEPA” have not demonstrated they meet the HEPA standard. Consumers should look to the product literature for documentation of the efficacy of these filters.
The Pollen-Free Clean Air Delivery Rate per Watt or Pollen CADR/W is the energy efficiency metric for room air cleaners. More efficient units have higher Pollen CADR/W.
The Rated Dust-Free Clean Air Delivery Rate or Dust CADR is the manufacturer-reported delivery of dust-free air produced by a household electric, cord-connected room air cleaner.
The Rated Smoke-Free Clean Air Delivery Rate or Smoke CADR is the manufacturer-reported delivery of smoke-free air produced by a household electric, cord-connected room air cleaner.

Indicates the secondary type of filter, if the air cleaner has more than one filter. High-Efficiency Particulate Air filters or HEPA filters sometimes, also called True HEPA filters, have a minimum fractional particle removal efficiency of 99.97% for all particles of 0.3 μm diameter. Filters described as HEPA-Type or something other than “HEPA” or “True HEPA” have not demonstrated they meet the HEPA standard. Consumers should look to the product literature for documentation of the efficacy of these filters.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a replacement filter by the manufacturer.

Indicates the third type of filter, if the air cleaner has more than two filters. High-Efficiency Particulate Air filters or HEPA filters sometimes, also called True HEPA filters, have a minimum fractional particle removal efficiency of 99.97% for all particles of 0.3 μm diameter. Filters described as HEPA-Type or something other than “HEPA” or “True HEPA” have not demonstrated they meet the HEPA standard. Consumers should look to the product literature for documentation of the efficacy of these filters.
The Rated Pollen-Free Clean Air Delivery Rate or Pollen CADR is the manufacturer-reported delivery of pollen-free air produced by a household electric, cord-connected room air cleaner.

This is the estimated annual energy use of the room air cleaner under typical conditions, including the energy used in active modes and partial on modes. It is calculated by multiplying the active mode hours by the smoke CADR divided by the smoke CADR/W and added to the inactive model hours multiplied by the partial on mode power. The active mode hours are assumed to be 5,840 hours per year and 2,920 for inactive mode hours, which is on average 16 hours active and 8 hours inactive per day. Actual energy consumption will vary depending on various factors such as the amount of usage in active mode and the settings chosen.
The average power in partial on mode, measured in Watts. Partial on mode includes standby and network connected power.
The Dust-Free Clean Air Delivery Rate per Watt or Dust CADR/W is the energy efficiency metric for room air cleaners. More efficient units have higher Dust CADR/W.
The Smoke-Free Clean Air Delivery Rate per Watt or Smoke CADR/W is the energy efficiency metric for room air cleaners. More efficient units have higher Smoke CADR/W.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a replacement filter by the manufacturer.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
Indicates all the standards and frameworks that apply for cyber security purposes.

Indicates if a module is needed to provide communication to enable entities outside the connected room air cleaner to provide energy consumption reporting to consumers and consumer-authorized energy use reporting third-parties.

To be recognized as connected, a room air cleaner needs to include the base room air cleaner plus all elements (hardware, software) required to enable communication in response to consumer authorized energy related commands (not including third-party remote management which may be made available solely at the discretion of the manufacturer).
Indicates which communication standards (e.g., Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, etc.) are offered.
Indicates whether the model is able to connect to a network.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria for 2023. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2023 criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a replacement filter by the manufacturer.

Indicates the fourth type of filter, if the air cleaner has more than three filters. High-Efficiency Particulate Air filters or HEPA filters sometimes, also called True HEPA filters, have a minimum fractional particle removal efficiency of 99.97% for all particles of 0.3 μm diameter. Filters described as HEPA-Type or something other than “HEPA” or “True HEPA” have not demonstrated they meet the HEPA standard. Consumers should look to the product literature for documentation of the efficacy of these filters.
The ozone emissions, measured in parts per billion.
Indicates the air cleaning technologies used by the room air cleaner, such as, fan and filter, fan with electrostatic plates, ion generator, and other technologies.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

Room size in square feet is calculated by multiplying the Smoke CADR by 1.55 or by 0.144 for square meters. This room size formula is based on the CADR requirement to remove 80% of smoke particles, assuming one room air exchange per hour.

The volume of water pumped in gallons per watt hour (Gal/Wh) of electrical energy consumed by the pump motor. Curve C Energy Factor is measured and reported at the intersection of the curve H=0.0082 x F2 and the pump curve for each Speed Setting. H is the total system head in feet of head, and F is the flow rate in gallons per minute (GPM).
The Hardware Architecture describes the type of module/device within or external to the system needed for connection.

The high-speed construction type of the motor included with the pool pump, which includes Capacitor Start - Capacitor Run, Capacitor Start - Induction Run, Electronically-commutated Motor, Permanent Split-capacitor Motor.

Options include single-speed, multi-speed, and variable-speed (including variable-flow). Single speed pumps operate at one speed. Multi-speed pumps typically have two speeds and use low speed for filtration and high speed for cleaning. Variable speed pumps have continuously adjustable pump speeds and variable flow pumps have continuously adjustable output (flow rate). Variable Speed pumps deliver consistent flow, as flow restriction changes.
The power draw when the pool pump is in Standby Power Mode. Only applicable to pool pumps with Standby Power Mode.
System can communicate using these protocols for sending messages and requests, some of which work wirelessly and some with wires (open standard media/network layer).
The number of impeller stages in product.
The flow rate in gallons per minute (GPM) at which the Energy Factor was measured.

The power measured at the low speed measurement point.
The power in watts (W) at which the Energy Factor was measured.

The volume of water pumped in gallons per watt hour (Gal/Wh) of electrical energy consumed by the pump motor. Curve A Energy Factor is measured and reported at the intersection of the curve H = 0.0167 x F2 and the pump curve for each Speed Setting. H is the total system head in feet of head, and F is the flow rate in gallons per minute (GPM).

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. The rotation speed of the pump at the high speed measurement point.

An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

Rated value for a measurement of pump efficiency (in kgal/kWh) based on performance at 1 or 2 DOE selected measurement points. For products with the ability to adjust speed while meeting flow needs, the WEF is able to account for energy savings from this adjustment.
The flow in GPM at the low speed measurement point for a product
The power measured at the high speed measurement point.
The flow rate in gallons per minute (GPM) at which the Energy Factor was measured.
A measurement  of the energy transferred to fluid flowing through the pump, calculated at max pump speed on Curve C, from the volume of fluid moved (gpm) and pressure (ftH2O).

The motor power output (HP) designed by the manufacturer for rated revolutions per minute (RPM), voltage and frequency. May be less than Total Horsepower where the Service Factor is > 1.0, or equal to Total Horsepower where the Service Factor = 1.0. Also known as Nameplate Horsepower.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

Options inlcude self priming pumps (for inground pools), non-self-priming pumps (for above ground pools), and pressure cleaner booster pumps (for additional pressure to operate certain pool cleaners).
The values here represent the minimum WEF the model is required to meet based on the configuration for minimum Federal Standards.

Indicates whether the model meets optional connected criteria as defined in the specification, which may include functions helpful to the electrical grid (standardized signals and responses to manage energy use) and those helpful to consumers, such as scheduling and energy reporting.
An external communication module or device is required if communication hardware is not built into the unit.
An external communication module or device is required if communication hardware is not built into the unit.
Network Standby Power (W).
The speed in revolutions per minute (RPM) at Maximum pump speed. Curve A/B/C data is recorded at this speed.
Is Pump equipped with freeze protection?
The head (vertical lift) supported by the pump at the low speed measurement point.
The head (vertical lift) supported by the pump at the high speed measurement point.

The volume of water pumped in gallons per watt hour (Gal/Wh) of electrical energy consumed by the pump motor. Curve B Energy Factor is measured and reported at the intersection of the curve H=0.050 x F2 and the pump curve for each Speed Setting. H is the total system head in feet of head, and F is the flow rate in gallons per minute (GPM).

columns_name: Meets ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2023 Criteria
Alternate Configuration Efficiency (Integrated Energy Factor - L/kWh)
columns_description: The date that the model is available for purchase.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria for 2023. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2023 criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
A measure of energy efficiency of a dehumidifier that encompasses dehumidification mode and non-dehumidification mode energy consumption.

Portable dehumidifiers operate within the dehumidified space without the attachment of additional ducting. Whole-home dehumidifiers are installed with ducting to deliver return process air to the inlet and to supply dehumidified process air from the outlet to one or more locations in the dehumidified space. Some dehumidifiers can operate in both configurations by means of a ducting kit.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.

A measure of a dehumidifier's ability to remove moisture from its surrounding atmosphere, measured in pints collected per 24 hours, based on DOE's Appendix X1 test method. This represents the expected performance in a basement for portable dehumidifiers and expected performance in the average home for whole-home dehumidifiers.

Some dehumidifiers can operate in both the portable and whole-home configurations by means of a ducting kit. For a dehumidifier sold as a whole-home type that can also operate as a portable type, the portable configuration is listed here as the alternate, and vice versa.

Some dehumidifiers can operate in an alternate configuration (e.g., a whole-home can operate as a portable) depending on how it is installed. This column indicates the efficiency of the dehumidifier in the configuration opposite of that listed under "Dehumidifier Type". If nothing is listed, the dehumidifier cannot operate in an alternate configuration.

An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. This column includes alternative means to identify the model/model family (e.g., additional model names, additional model numbers, retailer SKUs, product descriptions).
For whole-home dehumidifiers, this is a measure of the rectangular volume that the product case occupies, exclusive of any duct attachment collars or other external components.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

Some dehumidifiers can operate in an alternate configuration (e.g., a whole-home can operate as a portable) depending on how it is installed. This column indicates the  water removal capacity of the dehumidifier in the configuration opposite of that listed under "Dehumidifier Type". If nothing is listed, the dehumidifier cannot operate in an alternate configuration.
